verses.text: The king's heart is like a stream of water in the hand of the LORD; He directs it wherever He wishes.
verses.comment: This verse highlights God's sovereignty over rulers, suggesting that earthly authority is subject to God's will. Reflects the belief that all legitimate authority is ultimately from God. See also Romans 13:1.

verses.text: Every way of a person seems right in his own eyes, but the LORD weighs the heart.
verses.comment: God judges motives, not just actions. This underlines the importance of inner virtue and sincerity. Connects to Jesus’ teachings on purity of heart (Matt 5:8).

verses.text: To do righteousness and justice is more acceptable to the LORD than sacrifice.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the primacy of moral living over ritual. Alludes to the continuity of law and grace, a theme developed by Christ (Matt 9:13).

verses.text: Haughty eyes and a proud heart, the lamp of the wicked, is sin.
verses.comment: Warning against pride, which is the root of many sins. Liturgical prayers often confess pride as a fundamental fault, echoing this wisdom.

verses.text: The plans of the diligent lead surely to abundance, but everyone who is hasty comes only to poverty.
verses.comment: Teaches the virtue of diligence and patience over rashness—reflecting biblical calls to steady growth and perseverance.

verses.text: Getting treasures by a lying tongue is a fleeting vapor, a deadly snare.
verses.comment: Dishonest gain is temporary and dangerous. Echoes Jesus’ warnings about storing up treasures in heaven (Matt 6:19-21).

verses.text: The violence of the wicked will sweep them away, because they refuse to do what is just.
verses.comment: Shows how evil deeds bring their own destruction. Points to Divine justice, fulfilled in both judgment and mercy.

verses.text: The way of the guilty is crooked, but the conduct of the pure is upright.
verses.comment: Contrasts the fruit of sin and virtue, a central theme in Scripture. The pursuit of purity is essential for holiness.

verses.text: It is better to live in a corner of the housetop than with a quarrelsome wife in a spacious house.
verses.comment: Suggests choosing peace over comfort. Marriage is to reflect holy unity, echoing Christ’s sacrificial love for the Church (Eph 5:25-33).

verses.text: The soul of the wicked desires evil; his neighbor finds no mercy in his eyes.
verses.comment: Heart illustrates unrestrained evil. Christ calls believers to radical mercy toward neighbors—see Luke 10:25-37.

verses.text: When a scoffer is punished, the simple become wise; and when the wise are instructed, they gain knowledge.
verses.comment: Correction leads to growth and wisdom—a form of spiritual discipline. Instruction is vital for Christian formation.

verses.text: The Righteous One considers the house of the wicked, and brings down the wicked to ruin.
verses.comment: The capitalized 'Righteous One' can be seen as a messianic hint, alluding to Christ as the perfect judge.

verses.text: Whoever closes his ear to the cry of the poor will himself cry out and not be answered.
verses.comment: Care for the poor is commanded and deeply tied to salvation—see Jesus' parable of the sheep and goats. Active charity is divinely mandated.

verses.text: A gift offered in secret calms anger, and a concealed bribe in the bosom, strong wrath.
verses.comment: Addresses both the placating power and the moral dangers of gifts. Wisdom literature often explores the ethics of intent and action.

verses.text: When justice is done, it brings joy to the righteous but terror to evildoers.
verses.comment: True justice is restorative and comforting for the virtuous, but brings dread to the guilty. Echoes themes of judgment in the prophets.

verses.text: Whoever wanders from the way of understanding will rest in the assembly of the dead.
verses.comment: Warns against spiritual wandering. The phrase ‘assembly of the dead’ refers to Sheol—absence from the path of life leads to spiritual death.

verses.text: Whoever loves pleasure will become poor; whoever loves wine and oil will not become rich.
verses.comment: Moderation is a biblical value. Overindulgence in material pleasures undermines spiritual and earthly prosperity.

verses.text: The wicked becomes a ransom for the righteous, and the treacherous for the upright.
verses.comment: Wickedness leads to reversal of fortunes—the righteous are preserved. Foreshadows Christ’s redemptive work.

verses.text: It is better to live in a desert land than with a quarrelsome and fretful wife.
verses.comment: Echoes previous proverb about domestic peace. Endorses harmony and patience in family life—a spiritual value.

verses.text: Precious treasure and oil are in the dwelling of the wise, but a foolish person devours it.
verses.comment: Wisdom leads to stewardship and preservation of good things. Calls for prudent use of blessings.

verses.text: Whoever pursues righteousness and mercy will find life, righteousness, and honor.
verses.comment: Righteousness and mercy are divine attributes. Pursuing these leads not just to earthly honor but to everlasting life as promised in Christ.

verses.text: A wise man scales the city of the mighty and brings down the stronghold in which they trust.
verses.comment: Wisdom is more powerful than brute force. Strategic wisdom mirrors Christ's teachings on the transforming power of love and truth.

verses.text: Whoever guards his mouth and tongue keeps himself from trouble.
verses.comment: Self-control over speech is strongly encouraged throughout Scripture, including James’s epistle on the tongue’s dangers.

verses.text: Scoffer is the name of the proud and arrogant man who acts with reckless fury.
verses.comment: Condemns pride and contempt. God resists the proud but gives grace to the humble—see 1 Peter 5:5.

verses.text: The desire of the sluggard kills him, for his hands refuse to labor.
verses.comment: Laziness leads to ruin. Calls believers to diligent work and gives spiritual value to labor, which is echoed in Christian teaching on vocation.

verses.text: All day long he craves and craves, but the righteous gives and does not hold back.
verses.comment: Contrasts selfishness with generosity. Almsgiving is a key biblical virtue, encouraged repeatedly by Jesus.

verses.text: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination, especially when it is offered with evil intent.
verses.comment: Unworthy offerings, even religious ones, are repugnant to God without repentance. Relates to the necessity of true contrition before worship.

verses.text: A false witness will perish, but the person who listens will speak lastingly.
verses.comment: Truth endures while lies are temporary. God’s law emphasizes the importance of honest testimony for justice.

verses.text: A wicked man puts on a bold face, but the upright makes his way sure.
verses.comment: Integrity brings confidence. The upright path is secure because it aligns with Divine guidance.

verses.text: There is no wisdom, no understanding, and no counsel against the LORD.
verses.comment: All human intellect and strategy fail before God’s purposes. Echoes Divine omnipotence and sovereignty.

verses.text: The horse is prepared for the day of battle, but victory belongs to the LORD.
verses.comment: Preparation is important, but final success depends on God. Invites trust and reliance on Divine Providence above mere human effort.
